sentences.text: Entitlement to service connection for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

sentences.text: INTRODUCTION

rhetClass.text: INTRODUCTION

sentences.text: The Veteran served active duty in the U.S. Army from July 1968 to July 1970.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran served active duty in the U.S. Army from July 1968 to July 1970.

sentences.text: This case comes before the Board of Veterans' Appeals (Board) on appeal from a March 2014 rating decision issued by the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) Regional Office (RO) in Detroit, Michigan.

rhetClass.text: This case comes before the Board of Veterans' Appeals (Board) on appeal from a March 2014 rating decision issued by the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) Regional Office (RO) in Detroit, Michigan.

sentences.text: The rating decision denied the Veteran's claim for PTSD and he filed his notice of disagreement in March 2014.

rhetClass.text: The rating decision denied the Veteran's claim for PTSD and he filed his notice of disagreement in March 2014.

sentences.text: The Veteran timely filed his substantive appeal in June 2014.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran timely filed his substantive appeal in June 2014.

sentences.text: On July 18, 2017, the Veteran testified at a hearing before the undersigned Veterans Law Judge (VLJ), via videoconference.

rhetClass.text: On July 18, 2017, the Veteran testified at a hearing before the undersigned Veterans Law Judge (VLJ), via videoconference.

sentences.text: A transcript of the hearing is of record.

rhetClass.text: A transcript of the hearing is of record.

sentences.text: The Board advises the Veteran to submit an increased rating claim for his service-connected generalized anxiety disorder.

rhetClass.text: The Board advises the Veteran to submit an increased rating claim for his service-connected generalized anxiety disorder.

sentences.text: In the July 18, 2017 hearing, the Veteran claimed that his psychiatric condition was worse than the 30 percent rating assigned.

rhetClass.text: In the July 18, 2017 hearing, the Veteran claimed that his psychiatric condition was worse than the 30 percent rating assigned.

sentences.text: Prior to March 24, 2015, his statements would have been enough for the Board to infer an increased rating claim.

rhetClass.text: Prior to March 24, 2015, his statements would have been enough for the Board to infer an increased rating claim.

sentences.text: However, after March 24, 2015, an increased rating claim must be filed on the formal claim form, VA Form 526.

rhetClass.text: However, after March 24, 2015, an increased rating claim must be filed on the formal claim form, VA Form 526.

rhetClass.text: FINDING OF FACT

sentences.text: The Veteran is not currently diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran is not currently diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder.

rhetClass.text: CONCLUSION OF LAW

sentences.text: REASONS AND BASES FOR FINDING AND CONCLUSION

rhetClass.text: REASONS AND BASES FOR FINDING AND CONCLUSION

sentences.text: I.  VA's Duty to Notify & Assist

rhetClass.text: I.  VA's Duty to Notify & Assist

sentences.text: VA has a duty to notify and a duty to assist claimants in substantiating a claim for VA benefits.

rhetClass.text: VA has a duty to notify and a duty to assist claimants in substantiating a claim for VA benefits.

sentences.text: The duty to notify has been met.

rhetClass.text: The duty to notify has been met.

sentences.text: See the July 2011 VCAA letter.

rhetClass.text: See the July 2011 VCAA letter.

sentences.text: Neither the Veteran, nor his representative, has alleged prejudice with regard to notice.

rhetClass.text: Neither the Veteran, nor his representative, has alleged prejudice with regard to notice.

sentences.text: The Federal Court of Appeals has held that "absent extraordinary circumstances ... it is appropriate for the Board and the Veterans Court to address only those procedural arguments specifically raised by the veteran ...."

rhetClass.text: The Federal Court of Appeals has held that "absent extraordinary circumstances ... it is appropriate for the Board and the Veterans Court to address only those procedural arguments specifically raised by the veteran ...."

sentences.text: Scott v. McDonald, 789 F.3d 1375 (Fed. Cir. 2015).

rhetClass.text: Scott v. McDonald, 789 F.3d 1375 (Fed. Cir. 2015).

sentences.text: In light of the foregoing, nothing more is required.

rhetClass.text: In light of the foregoing, nothing more is required.

sentences.text: The Veterans Claims Assistance Act of 2000 (VCAA), codified in pertinent part at 38 U.S.C. Â§Â§ 5103, 5103A (2012), and the pertinent implementing regulation, codified at 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.159 (2017), provide that VA will assist a claimant in obtaining evidence necessary to substantiate a claim but is not required to provide assistance to a claimant if there is no reasonable possibility that such assistance would aid in substantiating the claim.

rhetClass.text: The Veterans Claims Assistance Act of 2000 (VCAA), codified in pertinent part at 38 U.S.C. Â§Â§ 5103, 5103A (2012), and the pertinent implementing regulation, codified at 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.159 (2017), provide that VA will assist a claimant in obtaining evidence necessary to substantiate a claim but is not required to provide assistance to a claimant if there is no reasonable possibility that such assistance would aid in substantiating the claim.

sentences.text: The record reflects that all available records pertinent to the claim have been obtained.

rhetClass.text: The record reflects that all available records pertinent to the claim have been obtained.

sentences.text: The Veteran has not identified any outstanding evidence that could be obtained to substantiate the claim; the Board is also unaware of any such evidence.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran has not identified any outstanding evidence that could be obtained to substantiate the claim; the Board is also unaware of any such evidence.

sentences.text: Accordingly, the Board will address the merits of the claims.

rhetClass.text: Accordingly, the Board will address the merits of the claims.

sentences.text: Service Connection Claims

rhetClass.text: Service Connection Claims

sentences.text: The Veteran asserts that he developed PTSD due to his active duty service.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran asserts that he developed PTSD due to his active duty service.

sentences.text: Service connection is granted for disability resulting from disease or injury that was incurred in or aggravated by active service.

rhetClass.text: Service connection is granted for disability resulting from disease or injury that was incurred in or aggravated by active service.

sentences.text: Additionally, service connection may be granted for any disease diagnosed after discharge, when all the evidence, including that pertinent to service, establishes that the disease was incurred in service.

rhetClass.text: Additionally, service connection may be granted for any disease diagnosed after discharge, when all the evidence, including that pertinent to service, establishes that the disease was incurred in service.

sentences.text: Entitlement to service connection benefits is established when the following elements are satisfied: (1) the existence of a current disability; (2) in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury; and (3) a causal relationship between the current disability and the disease or injury incurred or aggravated during service (the medical "nexus" requirement).

rhetClass.text: Entitlement to service connection benefits is established when the following elements are satisfied: (1) the existence of a current disability; (2) in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury; and (3) a causal relationship between the current disability and the disease or injury incurred or aggravated during service (the medical "nexus" requirement).

sentences.text: See Shedden v. Principi, 381 F.3d 1163, 1166-67 (Fed. Cir. 2004); 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.303(a) (2017).

rhetClass.text: See Shedden v. Principi, 381 F.3d 1163, 1166-67 (Fed. Cir. 2004); 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.303(a) (2017).

sentences.text: Service connection for PTSD requires medical evidence diagnosing the disorder in accordance with 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125(a); a link, established by medical evidence, between current symptoms and an in-service stressor; and credible supporting evidence that the in-service stressor occurred.

rhetClass.text: Service connection for PTSD requires medical evidence diagnosing the disorder in accordance with 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125(a); a link, established by medical evidence, between current symptoms and an in-service stressor; and credible supporting evidence that the in-service stressor occurred.

sentences.text: The evidence necessary to establish the occurrence of a recognizable stressor during service to support a diagnosis of PTSD will vary depending upon whether a veteran engaged in "combat with the enemy."

rhetClass.text: The evidence necessary to establish the occurrence of a recognizable stressor during service to support a diagnosis of PTSD will vary depending upon whether a veteran engaged in "combat with the enemy."

sentences.text: Gaines v. West, 11 Vet. App. 353 (1998).

rhetClass.text: Gaines v. West, 11 Vet. App. 353 (1998).

sentences.text: If VA determines that a veteran engaged in combat with the enemy and his alleged stressor is combat-related, then his lay testimony or statement is accepted as conclusive evidence of the stressor's occurrence and no further development or corroborative evidence is required, provided that such testimony is found to be "satisfactory," i.e., credible and "consistent with circumstances, disorders or hardships of service."

rhetClass.text: If VA determines that a veteran engaged in combat with the enemy and his alleged stressor is combat-related, then his lay testimony or statement is accepted as conclusive evidence of the stressor's occurrence and no further development or corroborative evidence is required, provided that such testimony is found to be "satisfactory," i.e., credible and "consistent with circumstances, disorders or hardships of service."

sentences.text: 38 U.S.C. Â§ 1154(b); 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.304(f)(1); see also Zarycki v. Brown, 6 Vet. App. 91 (1993).

rhetClass.text: 38 U.S.C. Â§ 1154(b); 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.304(f)(1); see also Zarycki v. Brown, 6 Vet. App. 91 (1993).

sentences.text: Where the veteran's alleged stressor was not combat related, then a veteran's lay testimony, alone, would not be sufficient to establish the occurrence of the alleged stressor; rather, corroborating evidence would be needed to support the claim for service connection.

rhetClass.text: Where the veteran's alleged stressor was not combat related, then a veteran's lay testimony, alone, would not be sufficient to establish the occurrence of the alleged stressor; rather, corroborating evidence would be needed to support the claim for service connection.

sentences.text: Cohen v. Brown, 10 Vet. App. 128 (1997); Moreau v. Brown, 9 Vet. App. 389 (1996).

rhetClass.text: Cohen v. Brown, 10 Vet. App. 128 (1997); Moreau v. Brown, 9 Vet. App. 389 (1996).

sentences.text: See also Zarycki, 6 Vet. App. at 98; Doran v. Brown, 6 Vet. App. 289 (1994).

rhetClass.text: See also Zarycki, 6 Vet. App. at 98; Doran v. Brown, 6 Vet. App. 289 (1994).

sentences.text: In July 2010, VA published a final rule that amended its adjudication regulations governing service connection for PTSD by relaxing, in certain circumstances, the evidentiary standard for establishing the required in-service stressor.

rhetClass.text: In July 2010, VA published a final rule that amended its adjudication regulations governing service connection for PTSD by relaxing, in certain circumstances, the evidentiary standard for establishing the required in-service stressor.

sentences.text: 75 Fed. Reg. 39843 (July 13, 2010) as amended by 75 Fed. Reg. 41092 (July 15, 2010) (providing the correct effective date of July 13, 2010, for the revised 38 C.F.R.

rhetClass.text: 75 Fed. Reg. 39843 (July 13, 2010) as amended by 75 Fed. Reg. 41092 (July 15, 2010) (providing the correct effective date of July 13, 2010, for the revised 38 C.F.R.

sentences.text: Specifically, the final rule amends 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.304(f) by re-designating current paragraphs (f)(3) and (f)(4) as paragraphs (f)(4) and (f)(5), respectively, and by adding a new paragraph (f)(3) that reads as follows:

rhetClass.text: Specifically, the final rule amends 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.304(f) by re-designating current paragraphs (f)(3) and (f)(4) as paragraphs (f)(4) and (f)(5), respectively, and by adding a new paragraph (f)(3) that reads as follows:

sentences.text: (f)(3) If a stressor claimed by a Veteran is related to the Veteran's fear of hostile military or terrorist activity and a VA psychiatrist or psychologist, or a psychiatrist or psychologist with whom VA has contracted, confirms that the claimed stressor is adequate to support a diagnosis of [PTSD] and that the Veteran's symptoms are related to the claimed stressor, in the absence of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, and provided the claimed stressor is consistent with the places, types, and circumstances of the Veteran's service, the Veteran's lay testimony alone may establish the occurrence of the claimed in-service stressor.

rhetClass.text: (f)(3) If a stressor claimed by a Veteran is related to the Veteran's fear of hostile military or terrorist activity and a VA psychiatrist or psychologist, or a psychiatrist or psychologist with whom VA has contracted, confirms that the claimed stressor is adequate to support a diagnosis of [PTSD] and that the Veteran's symptoms are related to the claimed stressor, in the absence of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, and provided the claimed stressor is consistent with the places, types, and circumstances of the Veteran's service, the Veteran's lay testimony alone may establish the occurrence of the claimed in-service stressor.

sentences.text: For purposes of this paragraph, "fear of hostile military or terrorist activity" means that a Veteran experienced, witnessed, or was confronted with an event or circumstance that involved actual or threatened death or serious injury, or a threat to the physical integrity of the Veteran or others, such as from an actual or potential improvised explosive device; vehicle-imbedded explosive device; incoming artillery, rocket, or mortar fire; grenade; small arms fire, including suspected sniper fire; or attack upon friendly military aircraft, and the Veteran's response to the event or circumstance involved a psychological or psycho-physiological state of fear, helplessness, or horror.

rhetClass.text: For purposes of this paragraph, "fear of hostile military or terrorist activity" means that a Veteran experienced, witnessed, or was confronted with an event or circumstance that involved actual or threatened death or serious injury, or a threat to the physical integrity of the Veteran or others, such as from an actual or potential improvised explosive device; vehicle-imbedded explosive device; incoming artillery, rocket, or mortar fire; grenade; small arms fire, including suspected sniper fire; or attack upon friendly military aircraft, and the Veteran's response to the event or circumstance involved a psychological or psycho-physiological state of fear, helplessness, or horror.

sentences.text: Id.

rhetClass.text: Id.

sentences.text: The revised Â§ 3.304(f) generally applies to claims of service connection for PTSD appealed to the Board on or after July 13, 2010.

rhetClass.text: The revised Â§ 3.304(f) generally applies to claims of service connection for PTSD appealed to the Board on or after July 13, 2010.

sentences.text: In this case, the claim for PTSD was appealed to the Board in June 2014, and therefore the revised regulation would be applicable.

rhetClass.text: In this case, the claim for PTSD was appealed to the Board in June 2014, and therefore the revised regulation would be applicable.

sentences.text: The Federal Circuit has limited the applicability of the revised Â§ 3.304(f) to appeals where "a claimed in-service PTSD stressor relates to an event or circumstance that a Veteran experienced, witnessed, or was confronted with and that was perpetrated by a member of an enemy military or by a terrorist."

rhetClass.text: The Federal Circuit has limited the applicability of the revised Â§ 3.304(f) to appeals where "a claimed in-service PTSD stressor relates to an event or circumstance that a Veteran experienced, witnessed, or was confronted with and that was perpetrated by a member of an enemy military or by a terrorist."

sentences.text: Hall v. Shinseki, 717 F.3d 1369 (Fed. Cir. 2013); see also Acevedo v. Shinseki, 25 Vet. App. 286 (2012) ("[T]he examples provided [in subsection (f)(3)] all involve actions originating from individuals who commit hostile military or terrorist acts toward the U.S. military, not nefarious, or even criminal, acts of one service member directed at another service

rhetClass.text: Hall v. Shinseki, 717 F.3d 1369 (Fed. Cir. 2013); see also Acevedo v. Shinseki, 25 Vet. App. 286 (2012) ("[T]he examples provided [in subsection (f)(3)] all involve actions originating from individuals who commit hostile military or terrorist acts toward the U.S. military, not nefarious, or even criminal, acts of one service member directed at another service

sentences.text: In making all determinations, the Board must fully consider the lay assertions of record.

rhetClass.text: In making all determinations, the Board must fully consider the lay assertions of record.

sentences.text: A layperson is competent to report on the onset and continuity of his current symptomatology.

rhetClass.text: A layperson is competent to report on the onset and continuity of his current symptomatology.

sentences.text: See Layno v. Brown, 6 Vet. App. 465, 470 (1994) (a Veteran is competent to report on that of which he or she has personal knowledge).

rhetClass.text: See Layno v. Brown, 6 Vet. App. 465, 470 (1994) (a Veteran is competent to report on that of which he or she has personal knowledge).

sentences.text: Lay evidence can also be competent and sufficient evidence of a diagnosis or to establish etiology if (1) the layperson is competent to identify the medical condition, (2) the layperson is reporting a contemporaneous medical diagnosis, or (3) lay testimony describing symptoms at the time supports a later diagnosis by a medical professional.

rhetClass.text: Lay evidence can also be competent and sufficient evidence of a diagnosis or to establish etiology if (1) the layperson is competent to identify the medical condition, (2) the layperson is reporting a contemporaneous medical diagnosis, or (3) lay testimony describing symptoms at the time supports a later diagnosis by a medical professional.

sentences.text: Davidson v. Shinseki, 581 F.3d 1313, 1316 (Fed. Cir. 2009); Jandreau v. Nicholson, 492 F.3d 1372, 1376-77 (Fed. Cir. 2007).

rhetClass.text: Davidson v. Shinseki, 581 F.3d 1313, 1316 (Fed. Cir. 2009); Jandreau v. Nicholson, 492 F.3d 1372, 1376-77 (Fed. Cir. 2007).

sentences.text: When considering whether lay evidence is competent the Board must determine, on a case-by-case basis, whether the Veteran's particular disability is the type of disability for which lay evidence may be competent.

rhetClass.text: When considering whether lay evidence is competent the Board must determine, on a case-by-case basis, whether the Veteran's particular disability is the type of disability for which lay evidence may be competent.

sentences.text: Kahana v. Shinseki, 24 Vet. App. 428 (2011); see also Jandreau at 1376-77.

rhetClass.text: Kahana v. Shinseki, 24 Vet. App. 428 (2011); see also Jandreau at 1376-77.

sentences.text: The Board must assess the credibility and weight of evidence.

rhetClass.text: The Board must assess the credibility and weight of evidence.

sentences.text: Madden v. Gober, 125 F.3d 1477, 1481 (Fed. Cir. 1997), cert.

rhetClass.text: Madden v. Gober, 125 F.3d 1477, 1481 (Fed. Cir. 1997), cert.

sentences.text: denied, 523 U.S. 1046 (1998); Wensch v. Principi, 15 Vet. App. 362, 367 (2001).

rhetClass.text: denied, 523 U.S. 1046 (1998); Wensch v. Principi, 15 Vet. App. 362, 367 (2001).

sentences.text: The Federal Circuit recognizes that the Board has an inherent fact-finding ability.

rhetClass.text: The Federal Circuit recognizes that the Board has an inherent fact-finding ability.

sentences.text: Jefferson v. Principi, 271 F.3d 1072, 1076 (Fed. Cir. 2001); see also 38 U.S.C. Â§ 7104(a).

rhetClass.text: Jefferson v. Principi, 271 F.3d 1072, 1076 (Fed. Cir. 2001); see also 38 U.S.C. Â§ 7104(a).

sentences.text: As a finder of fact, when considering whether lay evidence is satisfactory, the Board may also properly consider internal inconsistency of the statements, facial plausibility, and consistency with other evidence submitted on behalf of the Veteran, and the Veteran's demeanor when testifying at a hearing.

rhetClass.text: As a finder of fact, when considering whether lay evidence is satisfactory, the Board may also properly consider internal inconsistency of the statements, facial plausibility, and consistency with other evidence submitted on behalf of the Veteran, and the Veteran's demeanor when testifying at a hearing.

sentences.text: See Dalton v. Nicholson, 21 Vet. App. 23, 38 (2007); Caluza v. Brown, 7 Vet. App. 498, 511 (1995), aff'd per curiam, 78 F.3d 604 (Fed. Cir. 1996).

rhetClass.text: See Dalton v. Nicholson, 21 Vet. App. 23, 38 (2007); Caluza v. Brown, 7 Vet. App. 498, 511 (1995), aff'd per curiam, 78 F.3d 604 (Fed. Cir. 1996).

sentences.text: The standard of proof to be applied in decisions on claims for Veterans' benefits is set forth at 38 U.S.C. Â§ 5107 (2012).

rhetClass.text: The standard of proof to be applied in decisions on claims for Veterans' benefits is set forth at 38 U.S.C. Â§ 5107 (2012).

sentences.text: A claimant is entitled to the benefit of the doubt when there is an approximate balance of positive and negative evidence.

rhetClass.text: A claimant is entitled to the benefit of the doubt when there is an approximate balance of positive and negative evidence.

sentences.text: When a claimant seeks benefits and the evidence is in relative equipoise, the claimant prevails.

rhetClass.text: When a claimant seeks benefits and the evidence is in relative equipoise, the claimant prevails.

sentences.text: See Gilbert v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 49 (1990).

rhetClass.text: See Gilbert v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 49 (1990).

sentences.text: The preponderance of the evidence must be against the claim for benefits to be denied.

rhetClass.text: The preponderance of the evidence must be against the claim for benefits to be denied.

sentences.text: See Alemany v. Brown, 9 Vet. App. 518 (1996).

rhetClass.text: See Alemany v. Brown, 9 Vet. App. 518 (1996).

sentences.text: Here, the initial question for the Board is whether the Veteran has current diagnosis of PTSD.

rhetClass.text: Here, the initial question for the Board is whether the Veteran has current diagnosis of PTSD.

sentences.text: The Board finds that competent, credible, and probative evidence establishes that the Veteran does not have a current diagnosis of PTSD.

rhetClass.text: The Board finds that competent, credible, and probative evidence establishes that the Veteran does not have a current diagnosis of PTSD.

polarity.text: The Board finds that competent, credible, and probative evidence establishes that the Veteran does not have a current diagnosis of PTSD.

ruleID.text: The Board finds that competent, credible, and probative evidence establishes that the Veteran does not have a current diagnosis of PTSD.

sentences.text: A September 2013 private medical record reveals the Veteran was evaluated for his psychiatric condition.

rhetClass.text: A September 2013 private medical record reveals the Veteran was evaluated for his psychiatric condition.

sentences.text: In that record, the examiner Dr. M.B., diagnosed the Veteran with dysthymic disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, and impulse-control disorder not otherwise specified.

rhetClass.text: In that record, the examiner Dr. M.B., diagnosed the Veteran with dysthymic disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, and impulse-control disorder not otherwise specified.

sentences.text: The Veteran reported with complaints of anxiety, depression, irritability, bad mood, temper tantrums, fits of rage, and low tolerance for stress and frustration.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran reported with complaints of anxiety, depression, irritability, bad mood, temper tantrums, fits of rage, and low tolerance for stress and frustration.

sentences.text: The Veteran claimed he had PTSD.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran claimed he had PTSD.

sentences.text: The examiner, however, indicated the Veteran had PTSD symptoms, but did not diagnose him with PTSD.

rhetClass.text: The examiner, however, indicated the Veteran had PTSD symptoms, but did not diagnose him with PTSD.

sentences.text: The examiner's treatment included reducing anxiety, depression, and emotional psychological issues, and to rule out PTSD symptoms from the Veteran's war experiences.

rhetClass.text: The examiner's treatment included reducing anxiety, depression, and emotional psychological issues, and to rule out PTSD symptoms from the Veteran's war experiences.

sentences.text: In further treatment records from January 2014, the examiner indicated that the Veteran had PTSD symptoms that were chronic, but maintained the prior diagnoses of dysthymic disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, and impulse-control disorder not otherwise specified.

rhetClass.text: In further treatment records from January 2014, the examiner indicated that the Veteran had PTSD symptoms that were chronic, but maintained the prior diagnoses of dysthymic disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, and impulse-control disorder not otherwise specified.

sentences.text: PTSD symptoms are not the same thing as a PTSD diagnosis.

rhetClass.text: PTSD symptoms are not the same thing as a PTSD diagnosis.

sentences.text: This evidence does not document the presence of a PTSD diagnosis.

rhetClass.text: This evidence does not document the presence of a PTSD diagnosis.

polarity.text: This evidence does not document the presence of a PTSD diagnosis.

ruleID.text: This evidence does not document the presence of a PTSD diagnosis.

sentences.text: The Veteran was afforded a VA examination in February 2014 to evaluate his psychiatric condition.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran was afforded a VA examination in February 2014 to evaluate his psychiatric condition.

sentences.text: At that time, the examiner indicated that the Veteran's symptoms did not meet the diagnostic criteria for PTSD under DSM-5.

rhetClass.text: At that time, the examiner indicated that the Veteran's symptoms did not meet the diagnostic criteria for PTSD under DSM-5.

sentences.text: Specifically, the examiner summarized that the Veteran has some features of the disorder, but does not meet the full criteria for PTSD.

rhetClass.text: Specifically, the examiner summarized that the Veteran has some features of the disorder, but does not meet the full criteria for PTSD.

sentences.text: Historically and currently he has not experienced persistent recurrent symptoms of PTSD.

rhetClass.text: Historically and currently he has not experienced persistent recurrent symptoms of PTSD.

sentences.text: He, has however, experienced mild anxiety since service.

rhetClass.text: He, has however, experienced mild anxiety since service.

sentences.text: The examiner diagnosed the Veteran with generalized anxiety disorder.

rhetClass.text: The examiner diagnosed the Veteran with generalized anxiety disorder.

sentences.text: The examiner opined that the Veteran's claimed condition of PTSD was less likely than not incurred in or caused by the claimed in-service stressor, because the Veteran did not meet the criteria for PTSD.

rhetClass.text: The examiner opined that the Veteran's claimed condition of PTSD was less likely than not incurred in or caused by the claimed in-service stressor, because the Veteran did not meet the criteria for PTSD.

sentences.text: Likewise, in a May 2014 C&P medical opinion, the examiner stated that the Veteran does not meet the criteria for PTSD, but did develop generalized anxiety symptoms due to his active duty service.

rhetClass.text: Likewise, in a May 2014 C&P medical opinion, the examiner stated that the Veteran does not meet the criteria for PTSD, but did develop generalized anxiety symptoms due to his active duty service.

sentences.text: There is no statement from any health care professional produced during the appeal period which includes a valid diagnosis of PTSD which is attributed to the Veteran's active duty service.

rhetClass.text: There is no statement from any health care professional produced during the appeal period which includes a valid diagnosis of PTSD which is attributed to the Veteran's active duty service.

polarity.text: There is no statement from any health care professional produced during the appeal period which includes a valid diagnosis of PTSD which is attributed to the Veteran's active duty service.

ruleID.text: There is no statement from any health care professional produced during the appeal period which includes a valid diagnosis of PTSD which is attributed to the Veteran's active duty service.

sentences.text: The Board acknowledges the Veteran's lay testimony that he suffers from PTSD, but the Veteran does not have the requisite medical training or experience to diagnose a psychiatric condition, therefore his statements are not competent with regard to what diagnosis to assign to his mental health symptoms.

rhetClass.text: The Board acknowledges the Veteran's lay testimony that he suffers from PTSD, but the Veteran does not have the requisite medical training or experience to diagnose a psychiatric condition, therefore his statements are not competent with regard to what diagnosis to assign to his mental health symptoms.

sentences.text: In summary, the Board finds that the most competent, credible, and probative evidence of record does not show that the Veteran currently or at any point during the appeal period has a valid diagnosis of PTSD based on competent medical evidence.

rhetClass.text: In summary, the Board finds that the most competent, credible, and probative evidence of record does not show that the Veteran currently or at any point during the appeal period has a valid diagnosis of PTSD based on competent medical evidence.

polarity.text: In summary, the Board finds that the most competent, credible, and probative evidence of record does not show that the Veteran currently or at any point during the appeal period has a valid diagnosis of PTSD based on competent medical evidence.

ruleID.text: In summary, the Board finds that the most competent, credible, and probative evidence of record does not show that the Veteran currently or at any point during the appeal period has a valid diagnosis of PTSD based on competent medical evidence.

ruleTree.label: The veteran has a disability that is service-connected.

nodes.label: The veteran has a present disability.
The veteranâ€™s claim is for PTSD, and the veteran presently has a diagnosis of PTSD supported by medical evidence diagnosing the condition in accordance with 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125(a).
The veteran suffered an in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury in line of duty.
The veteran suffered an in-service incurrence of a disease or injury.
The veteran suffered an injury or contracted a disease during active military service.
The veteranâ€™s claim is for PTSD, and there is credible supporting evidence that the claimed in-service stressor occurred.
There is adequate evidence that the veteran suffered from the claimed disease or injury while in service.
The injury or disease did not preexist entry into service.
The veteran is presumed to have been in sound condition when examined, accepted, and enrolled for service (the presumption of sound condition or presumption of soundness).

The veteran served in the active military, naval, or air service, during a period of war or after December 31, 1946, and clear and unmistakable evidence demonstrates that the injury or disease existed before acceptance and enrollment and was not aggravated by such service.
The veteran suffered an in-service aggravation of a disease or injury.
The injury or disease preexisted entry into service.
There was an aggravation during service.
The presumption of aggravation has been satisfied.
Based on clear and unmistakable evidence (obvious or manifest) that is undebatable, there is a specific finding that the increase in disability is due to the natural progress of the disease.
The disability is a result of the veteranâ€™s own willful misconduct or abuse of alcohol or drugs.
There is a causal relationship [nexus] between the present disability and the injury, disease, or aggravation of a preexisting injury or disease incurred during active duty.
The veteranâ€™s claim is for PTSD, and there is a link, established by medical evidence, between current symptoms and an in-service stressor.

text:
Citation Nr: 1803350	
Decision Date: 01/18/18    Archive Date: 01/29/18

DOCKET NO.  14-22 524	)	DATE
	)
	)

On appeal from the
Department of Veterans Affairs Regional Office in Detroit, Michigan


THE ISSUE

Entitlement to service connection for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).


REPRESENTATION

Veteran represented by:	Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States


WITNESSES AT HEARING ON APPEAL

Veteran and Spouse


ATTORNEY FOR THE BOARD

I. Umo, Associate Counsel


INTRODUCTION

The Veteran served active duty in the U.S. Army from July 1968 to July 1970.

This case comes before the Board of Veterans' Appeals (Board) on appeal from a March 2014 rating decision issued by the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) Regional Office (RO) in Detroit, Michigan.  The rating decision denied the Veteran's claim for PTSD and he filed his notice of disagreement in March 2014.  The Veteran timely filed his substantive appeal in June 2014.

On July 18, 2017, the Veteran testified at a hearing before the undersigned Veterans Law Judge (VLJ), via videoconference.  A transcript of the hearing is of record.

The Board advises the Veteran to submit an increased rating claim for his service-connected generalized anxiety disorder.  In the July 18, 2017 hearing, the Veteran claimed that his psychiatric condition was worse than the 30 percent rating assigned.  Prior to March 24, 2015, his statements would have been enough for the Board to infer an increased rating claim.  However, after March 24, 2015, an increased rating claim must be filed on the formal claim form, VA Form 526.


FINDING OF FACT

The Veteran is not currently diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder.


CONCLUSION OF LAW

The criteria for service connection for post-traumatic stress disorder have not been met.  38 U.S.C. Â§Â§ 1110, 5107 (2012); 38 C.F.R. Â§Â§ 3.102, 3.303, 3.304 (2017).




REASONS AND BASES FOR FINDING AND CONCLUSION

I.  VA's Duty to Notify & Assist

VA has a duty to notify and a duty to assist claimants in substantiating a claim for VA benefits.  38 U.S.C. Â§Â§ 5100, 5102, 5103, 5103A and 5107 (2012); 38 C.F.R. Â§Â§ 3.102, 3.156(a), 3.159, 3.326(a) (2017); see also Quartuccio v. Principi, 16 Vet. App. 183, 187 (2002).

The duty to notify has been met.  See the July 2011 VCAA letter.  Neither the Veteran, nor his representative, has alleged prejudice with regard to notice.  The Federal Court of Appeals has held that "absent extraordinary circumstances ... it is appropriate for the Board and the Veterans Court to address only those procedural arguments specifically raised by the veteran ...."  Scott v. McDonald, 789 F.3d 1375 (Fed. Cir. 2015).  In light of the foregoing, nothing more is required.

The Veterans Claims Assistance Act of 2000 (VCAA), codified in pertinent part at 38 U.S.C. Â§Â§ 5103, 5103A (2012), and the pertinent implementing regulation, codified at 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.159 (2017), provide that VA will assist a claimant in obtaining evidence necessary to substantiate a claim but is not required to provide assistance to a claimant if there is no reasonable possibility that such assistance would aid in substantiating the claim.  

The record reflects that all available records pertinent to the claim have been obtained.  The Veteran has not identified any outstanding evidence that could be obtained to substantiate the claim; the Board is also unaware of any such evidence.  

Accordingly, the Board will address the merits of the claims.

Service Connection Claims

The Veteran asserts that he developed PTSD due to his active duty service.

Service connection is granted for disability resulting from disease or injury that was incurred in or aggravated by active service.  38 U.S.C. Â§Â§ 1110, 1131 (2012);        38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.303(a) (2017).  Additionally, service connection may be granted for any disease diagnosed after discharge, when all the evidence, including that pertinent to service, establishes that the disease was incurred in service.                 38 C.F.R. Â§3.303(d).

Entitlement to service connection benefits is established when the following elements are satisfied: (1) the existence of a current disability; (2) in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury; and (3) a causal relationship between the current disability and the disease or injury incurred or aggravated during service (the medical "nexus" requirement).  See Shedden v. Principi, 381 F.3d 1163, 1166-67 (Fed. Cir. 2004); 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.303(a) (2017).

Service connection for PTSD requires medical evidence diagnosing the disorder in accordance with 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125(a); a link, established by medical evidence, between current symptoms and an in-service stressor; and credible supporting evidence that the in-service stressor occurred.  38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.304(f).

The evidence necessary to establish the occurrence of a recognizable stressor during service to support a diagnosis of PTSD will vary depending upon whether a veteran engaged in "combat with the enemy."  Gaines v. West, 11 Vet. App. 353 (1998).  If VA determines that a veteran engaged in combat with the enemy and his alleged stressor is combat-related, then his lay testimony or statement is accepted as conclusive evidence of the stressor's occurrence and no further development or corroborative evidence is required, provided that such testimony is found to be "satisfactory," i.e., credible and "consistent with circumstances, disorders or hardships of service."  38 U.S.C. Â§ 1154(b); 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.304(f)(1); see also Zarycki v. Brown, 6 Vet. App. 91 (1993). 

Where the veteran's alleged stressor was not combat related, then a veteran's lay testimony, alone, would not be sufficient to establish the occurrence of the alleged stressor; rather, corroborating evidence would be needed to support the claim for service connection.  Cohen v. Brown, 10 Vet. App. 128 (1997); Moreau v. Brown, 9 Vet. App. 389 (1996).  See also Zarycki, 6 Vet. App. at 98; Doran v. Brown, 6 Vet. App. 289 (1994).

In July 2010, VA published a final rule that amended its adjudication regulations governing service connection for PTSD by relaxing, in certain circumstances, the evidentiary standard for establishing the required in-service stressor.  75 Fed. Reg. 39843 (July 13, 2010) as amended by 75 Fed. Reg. 41092 (July 15, 2010) (providing the correct effective date of July 13, 2010, for the revised 38 C.F.R. 
Â§ 3.304(f)).  Specifically, the final rule amends 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.304(f) by re-designating current paragraphs (f)(3) and (f)(4) as paragraphs (f)(4) and (f)(5), respectively, and by adding a new paragraph (f)(3) that reads as follows: 

(f)(3) If a stressor claimed by a Veteran is related to the Veteran's fear of hostile military or terrorist activity and a VA psychiatrist or psychologist, or a psychiatrist or psychologist with whom VA has contracted, confirms that the claimed stressor is adequate to support a diagnosis of [PTSD] and that the Veteran's symptoms are related to the claimed stressor, in the absence of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, and provided the claimed stressor is consistent with the places, types, and circumstances of the Veteran's service, the Veteran's lay testimony alone may establish the occurrence of the claimed in-service stressor.  For purposes of this paragraph, "fear of hostile military or terrorist activity" means that a Veteran experienced, witnessed, or was confronted with an event or circumstance that involved actual or threatened death or serious injury, or a threat to the physical integrity of the Veteran or others, such as from an actual or potential improvised explosive device; vehicle-imbedded explosive device; incoming artillery, rocket, or mortar fire; grenade; small arms fire, including suspected sniper fire; or attack upon friendly military aircraft, and the Veteran's response to the event or circumstance involved a psychological or psycho-physiological state of fear, helplessness, or horror.  Id.  

The revised Â§ 3.304(f) generally applies to claims of service connection for PTSD appealed to the Board on or after July 13, 2010.  In this case, the claim for PTSD was appealed to the Board in June 2014, and therefore the revised regulation would be applicable.

The Federal Circuit has limited the applicability of the revised Â§ 3.304(f) to appeals where "a claimed in-service PTSD stressor relates to an event or circumstance that a Veteran experienced, witnessed, or was confronted with and that was perpetrated by a member of an enemy military or by a terrorist."  Hall v. Shinseki, 717 F.3d 1369 (Fed. Cir. 2013); see also Acevedo v. Shinseki, 25 Vet. App. 286 (2012) ("[T]he examples provided [in subsection (f)(3)] all involve actions originating from individuals who commit hostile military or terrorist acts toward the U.S. military, not nefarious, or even criminal, acts of one service member directed at another service

In making all determinations, the Board must fully consider the lay assertions of record.  A layperson is competent to report on the onset and continuity of his current symptomatology.  See Layno v. Brown, 6 Vet. App. 465, 470 (1994) (a Veteran is competent to report on that of which he or she has personal knowledge).
Lay evidence can also be competent and sufficient evidence of a diagnosis or to establish etiology if (1) the layperson is competent to identify the medical condition, (2) the layperson is reporting a contemporaneous medical diagnosis, or (3) lay testimony describing symptoms at the time supports a later diagnosis by a medical professional.  Davidson v. Shinseki, 581 F.3d 1313, 1316 (Fed. Cir. 2009); Jandreau v. Nicholson, 492 F.3d 1372, 1376-77 (Fed. Cir. 2007).

When considering whether lay evidence is competent the Board must determine, on a case-by-case basis, whether the Veteran's particular disability is the type of disability for which lay evidence may be competent.  Kahana v. Shinseki, 24 Vet. App. 428 (2011); see also Jandreau at 1376-77.

The Board must assess the credibility and weight of evidence.  Madden v. Gober, 125 F.3d 1477, 1481 (Fed. Cir. 1997), cert. denied, 523 U.S. 1046 (1998); Wensch v. Principi, 15 Vet. App. 362, 367 (2001).  The Federal Circuit recognizes that the Board has an inherent fact-finding ability.  Jefferson v. Principi, 271 F.3d 1072, 1076 (Fed. Cir. 2001); see also 38 U.S.C. Â§ 7104(a).  As a finder of fact, when considering whether lay evidence is satisfactory, the Board may also properly consider internal inconsistency of the statements, facial plausibility, and consistency with other evidence submitted on behalf of the Veteran, and the Veteran's demeanor when testifying at a hearing.  See Dalton v. Nicholson, 21 Vet. App. 23, 38 (2007); Caluza v. Brown, 7 Vet. App. 498, 511 (1995), aff'd per curiam, 78 F.3d 604 (Fed. Cir. 1996).

The standard of proof to be applied in decisions on claims for Veterans' benefits is set forth at 38 U.S.C. Â§ 5107 (2012).  A claimant is entitled to the benefit of the doubt when there is an approximate balance of positive and negative evidence.  See 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.102.  When a claimant seeks benefits and the evidence is in relative equipoise, the claimant prevails.  See Gilbert v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 49 (1990).  The preponderance of the evidence must be against the claim for benefits to be denied.  See Alemany v. Brown, 9 Vet. App. 518 (1996).

Here, the initial question for the Board is whether the Veteran has current diagnosis of PTSD.

The Board finds that competent, credible, and probative evidence establishes that the Veteran does not have a current diagnosis of PTSD.

A September 2013 private medical record reveals the Veteran was evaluated for his psychiatric condition.  In that record, the examiner Dr. M.B., diagnosed the Veteran with dysthymic disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, and impulse-control disorder not otherwise specified.  The Veteran reported with complaints of anxiety, depression, irritability, bad mood, temper tantrums, fits of rage, and low tolerance for stress and frustration.  The Veteran claimed he had PTSD.  The examiner, however, indicated the Veteran had PTSD symptoms, but did not diagnose him with PTSD.  The examiner's treatment included reducing anxiety, depression, and emotional psychological issues, and to rule out PTSD symptoms from the Veteran's war experiences.  In further treatment records from January 2014, the examiner indicated that the Veteran had PTSD symptoms that were chronic, but maintained the prior diagnoses of dysthymic disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, and impulse-control disorder not otherwise specified.  PTSD symptoms are not the same thing as a PTSD diagnosis.  This evidence does not document the presence of a PTSD diagnosis.  

The Veteran was afforded a VA examination in February 2014 to evaluate his psychiatric condition.  At that time, the examiner indicated that the Veteran's symptoms did not meet the diagnostic criteria for PTSD under DSM-5.  Specifically, the examiner summarized that the Veteran has some features of the disorder, but does not meet the full criteria for PTSD.  Historically and currently he has not experienced persistent recurrent symptoms of PTSD.  He, has however, experienced mild anxiety since service.  The examiner diagnosed the Veteran with generalized anxiety disorder.  The examiner opined that the Veteran's claimed condition of PTSD was less likely than not incurred in or caused by the claimed in-service stressor, because the Veteran did not meet the criteria for PTSD.  Likewise, in a May 2014 C&P medical opinion, the examiner stated that the Veteran does not meet the criteria for PTSD, but did develop generalized anxiety symptoms due to his active duty service.  

There is no statement from any health care professional produced during the appeal period which includes a valid diagnosis of PTSD which is attributed to the Veteran's active duty service.  

The Board acknowledges the Veteran's lay testimony that he suffers from PTSD, but the Veteran does not have the requisite medical training or experience to diagnose a psychiatric condition, therefore his statements are not competent with regard to what diagnosis to assign to his mental health symptoms.  

In summary, the Board finds that the most competent, credible, and probative evidence of record does not show that the Veteran currently or at any point during the appeal period has a valid diagnosis of PTSD based on competent medical evidence.  Additionally, the Board notes that the Veteran is already service-connected for anxiety disorder therefore an acquired psychiatric disorder has been determined.  

Accordingly, based on the foregoing reasons, the claim for service connection for PTSD must be denied.  In reaching this conclusion, the Board has considered the applicability of the benefit-of-the-doubt doctrine; however, as the preponderance of the evidence is against the Veteran's claim, that doctrine is not applicable.






ORDER

Entitlement to service connection for PTSD is denied.  



____________________________________________
G. A. Wasik
Veterans Law Judge, Board of Veterans' Appeals



Department of Veterans Affairs
